abstract.text: A custom action that your app can perform in response to a remote or local notification.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: When a notification is delivered, the system displays a button for each custom action associated with the notification. Tapping a button launches your app (either in the foreground or background) and gives you a chance to perform the indicated action. You use this class to specify the text that is displayed in the button and the information your app needs to perform the corresponding action.
Typically, you create an instance of the

class instead of this class. You use the mutable object to configure the action and then call the setActions:forContext: method of UIMutableUserNotificationActionSettings to add the resulting actions to a group.

For each action you define, you must specify whether execution of that action requires the app to be running in the foreground or background. You can also specify whether the device must be unlocked or can remain locked while the action is performed. Unlocking the device may be necessary if the action involves reading or writing files that are encrypted on disk using the system’s data protection mechanism. When the user selects an action, the system puts your app into the appropriate mode and calls your app delegate’s

abstract.text: A task your app performs in response to a notification that the system delivers.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An acceleration event that represents immediate, three-dimensional acceleration data.
An object that lets you register to receive acceleration-related data from the onboard hardware.
A view that presents a set of alternatives for how to proceed with a task.
A view that displays an alert message.
Called when your app has been activated because user selected a custom action from the alert panel of a local notification.
Tells the app delegate to perform the custom action specified by a remote notification.
A list of all the available document providers for a given file type and mode, in addition to custom menu items that you add.
A notification that an app can schedule for presentation at a specific date and time.
The menu interface for the Cut, Copy, Paste, Select, Select All, and Delete commands.
A custom item in the editing menu managed by the menu controller.
A modifiable version of the user notification action class.
Information about custom actions that your app can perform in response to a local or push notification.
An object that manages the presentation of content in a popover.
A preview action, or
, that displays below a peek when a user swipes the peek upward.
A group of one or more child quick actions, each an instance of the preview action class.
An object that manages the display of a search bar, along with a table view that displays search results.
A specific type of segue for presenting content in a popover.
A custom action that your app can perform in response to a remote or local notification.
The mode in which to run the app when the action is performed.
The custom behavior (if any) that the action supports.
The string that you use internally to identify the action.
Creates a user notification action.
Creates a user notification action from data in an unarchiver.
A Boolean value indicating whether the user must unlock the device before the action is performed.
A Boolean value indicating whether the action is destructive.
A dictionary of additional parameters to include with the action.
The localized string to use as the button title for the action.
Constants indicating additional behavior that the action supports.
Constants indicating whether the app should activate to the foreground or background.
Information about custom actions that your app can perform in response to a local or push notification.
The types of notifications that can be displayed to the user by your app.
Key to include among the parameters of the action.
Key related to action-related behaviors.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
A protocol that mutable objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
